entry.title: Re: Getting the list of transport requests which will be...
entry.content:
Hello Bruno,

You can find the ‚ÄúTransport Analysis‚Äù card via the ‚ÄúCross-Project Overview‚Äù app. Here is what the In-App Help says bout this app:

"In the Transport Analysis app, you get an overview of all your system transports. You can search transports and check which feature they are assigned to.

You can do the following with this app:

  • View assigned transports
  • View where transports are deployed
  • View the stage of a transport
  • View affected features of a failed transport
  • Search all transports in Production
  • View all source tenants
  • View transports that are not yet assigned to Features"

Maybe this helps.

Best regards

Katja

entry.title: SAP Public Cloud / Problem with the Migration of Contact Persons
entry.content:
Hello Experts,
i have a question about the best way to migrate a complex structure of contact persons. Our goul is that the migrated business partners have their associated contact persons in the "contacts" section in the general view of the app "Manage Business Partner Master Data" (compare screenshot). 

The issue is, that there are a few Business Partners that share the same contact person. If we only use the Migration Cockpit and the "customer" migration object, we would, from our understanding, create the same contact person multiple times if we tried to enter them in the contact person section of that migration template, because it always creates a new contact person for every entry. 
Given that, the next logical step would be to migrate the contact persons and the other business partners seperatly and then fix the issue with mass maintenace after that.
My question is, are there apps to mass maintain this information and if so, how is the process ? Or is this a limitation of the Public Cloud and we need to do this manually ?

Best regards
Lukas

entry.title: Re: What exactly is SAP BW PCE‚Ä¶ and what it is not !
entry.content:
Dear Max
yes, of course you can convert to SAP BW/4HANA at any time afterward, and also before the "lift&shift".
"Before" means you perform the conversion with the current set up of SMEs in the on-premise environment.
"Afterward" means SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS), who operate the PCE system for you, will to the technical conversion. 
The preparation, which normally consumes most of the BW/4HANA conversion effort, will still rely on your resources in both cases.
Regards Frank

entry.title: Re: Issue with Company Code and Purchasing Details Not Up...
entry.content:
Possible root cause could be missing Role segment in Payload. The API_BUSINESS_PARTNER requires specific segments for each BP role:

  • Company Code Data ‚Üí BusinessPartnerRole = FLVN00 (Vendor: FI role)
  • Purchasing Data ‚Üí BusinessPartnerRole = FLVN01 (Vendor: Purchasing role)

If these roles or their associated data structures are missing or incomplete in the CPI payload, SAP will create the BP but skip those details.

entry.content:
In the Windows services you will find the sap cloud print service and the SAP cloud print watcher screenshot (CPM1)

While the SAP Cloud Print Service needs to be started as shown in screenshot (CPM2) even with a local windows admin user.

entry.title: Re: Stock Quantity and Total Stock are not equal in TC: MB5K
entry.content:
While it is not clear from your post as to whether any recent changes happened to material master data for these materials, some of the root causes are

  • Valuation area 5792 may have inconsistent settings or missing account determination.
  • The material may have stock quantity but no value, or vice versa. This often happens if Goods movements were posted without proper valuation and Material master lacks correct valuation class or price control settings.
  • If Price Control is set to Standard (S) but no standard price is maintained, the system cannot calculate value. If set to Moving Average (V), and goods are received without price, value may be zero.
  • Goods receipts or issues may be posted without proper accounting entries. Check for material documents without accounting documents (use MB51 and MB03).
  • If the material is managed in a different unit or currency, conversion issues may cause value mismatch.

entry.title: Understanding Release Contracts (C0‚ÄìC3) in S/4HANA Repository Objects
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the first in a short series about extension and API stability in S/4HANA. In this post I‚Äôll explain release contracts (also known as stability contracts) ‚Äî what they are, why SAP uses them, and how they affect the objects you work with every day.

A Release Contract is a classification that indicates how stable a repository object is and how it can be used or extended. It‚Äôs SAP‚Äôs formal promise that certain objects will remain stable across upgrades. The goal is to strike a balance: on one hand, SAP keeps the system flexible so development can continue; on the other, key technical elements are kept stable so consumers don‚Äôt need to rewrite code after every upgrade.

To provide those guarantees, SAP defines different stability/release contracts (C0, C1, C2, ‚Ä¶). Each contract describes the intended scope of use ‚Äî for example, whether something is intended as a safe extension point, a stable in-system API, or a remote API for external callers.

Stability Contracts

       C0 : Contract for Extensions

       C1 : Contract for System Internal Use

       C2 : Contract for Remote API Use

       C3 : Manage Configuration Content

       C4 : Use in ABAP Managed Database Procedure ( Not covered in this blog )

Let us look at how these Contracts apply to comman repository Objects.

CDS Views : CDS views are one of the most common repository objects you‚Äôll come across in S/4HANA. SAP uses release contracts to make clear whether a CDS view can be extended, consumed inside the system, or even exposed to the outside world.

  • C0 - Extend

    • A C0 contract means the CDS view can be safely extended
    • There are two main ways to extend
      • Key user Extensibility : add your own custom fields (or sometimes even make standard fields available) using the Custom Fields app in FIORI.
      • Developer Extensibility : Use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) to create a CDS view extension. This lets you add fields or annotations to the view in a controlled way.
    • The promise here is that the structure of the view won‚Äôt change in a way that breaks your code across upgrades.

            

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the CDS view is a stable API for internal consumption.

    • You can safely use a C1 released CDS in :
      • Key user Extensibility : For Analytical Queries, Custom CDS Views
      • Developer Extensibility : In Custom ABAP code in ABAP Cloud or S/4 HANA Cloud.
    • In both cases, the base CDS view provides stable ‚Äúanchors‚Äù where your extensions will survive upgrades.

          

  • C2 - Remote APIs

    • Sometimes the data in a CDS view isn‚Äôt just needed internally, but also by external systems.

    • In those cases, SAP exposes the CDS via an OData service (or other service binding).
    • When a CDS view is published for remote consumption, it carries a C2 contract. This ensures the external API is technically stable for side-by-side or third-party integrations.

                

 

Database Tables : Database tables are the lowest-level repository objects in the system. In Practice SAP most often delivers these with C3 ( Manage Configuration Content ).

Tables can also be prepared by the provider for C0 ( Developer Extensibility ) using specific Annotation and release state settings - but this is an opt-in decision design. Most standard tables are not exposed this way , because SAP prefers that extensions happen via CDS views.

The release contract you‚Äôll find for tables is C3 ‚Äì Manage Configuration Content.

  • C3 - Manage Configuration Content

    • A C3 contract means the table is intended for storing configuration data (for example, customizing or setup values).
    • With C3, SAP promises that the persistence and structure of the table will remain stable so that tools can reliably export, import, or transport configuration across systems.
  • Why Not C0 or C1 for tables ?
    • No C1: Tables are not meant to be consumed directly in ABAP Cloud development. If you need business data, you should always go through a released CDS view
    • C0 possible but rare : SAP does allow tables to be released with C0 if explicitly enabled by the provider (using annotations), but most delivered tables are not. Instead, SAP recommends CDS views or the Custom Fields app for extensibility. 

          

 

Behavior Defination ( RAP Business Object ) : Behavior definitions describe what you can do with a business object in RAP (the RESTful ABAP Programming Model) ‚Äî things like creating, updating, deleting, running validations, or triggering actions. 

Unlike CDS views, most SAP-delivered behavior definitions are released with C1 (System-Internal Use). A C0 contract for behavior definitions is technically possible (the framework supports it if the provider enables extension anchors), but in practice it is rare. You should always check the API State in ADT to see what‚Äôs allowed.

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the business object is safe to consume inside the system, but not open for developer extensions. 
    • You Can :
      • Call the BO‚Äôs actions and operations in your own ABAP Cloud code.
      • Bind the BO to a Fiori Elements app and use it in your custom applications.
      • Rely on its structure to remain stable across upgrades.

 

Conclusion

This blog focused on SAP-delivered objects and how SAP marks their stability (C0‚ÄìC3): CDS views (C0 for extension, C1 for in-system use, C2 for remote APIs), behavior definitions (generally C1 for consumption; C0 only if explicitly enabled), and database tables (commonly C3 for configuration; tables can also be prepared for C0, but that is opt-in).. Although there are other blogs that go deep into specific object types, this post is meant as a pre-read to give you the holistic view. And if you want to actually find released objects and their contracts, the magic lies in the System Library in ADT ‚Äî and how you configure the tree.

entry.title: Re: Time off Finland - accrual rules and best practices p...
entry.content:
Hi @laurasanchezf 

We discussed with stakeholders who gave us these requirements. There are two parts

1) Parental Leave for multiple children:  This can be best handled using this blog where you could have for example three-time types for each child (one) and then you can count those time types within the accrual rule just like any other time type 

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/parental-leave-ireland-solution-proposal-in-successfactors-time-management/ba-p/13579269

2) Regarding the counting mechanism itself. Our stakeholders mentioned that if we are counting the days/limit including the Saturday , it should also be counted the same way when deducting this for 14 day rule. Counting based on deduction (sat) for limit and using them in a different way (working day) in the rule is not in sync. Perhaps this part is more customer specific, and it is challenging to address different units in counting limits but using them in working days in accrual rule deduction to cater to 14 day rule

Perhaps what can be done is if the limit is 5 -10 days , then you could deduct 1 working day. 10-15 days -> 2 working days etc from overall limit which was exceeded (in this example 12 days). This may not be very accurate though

@monicareidl 

Thanks & Regards

Neelesh

entry.title: Re: Use case of MMRV
entry.content: Even though OMSY can set the initial period and allow postings to the previous period during setup, MMRV is the operational tool used to enable or disable backposting during regular business operations. It ensures flexibility for delayed entries without compromising period integrity.

entry.title: Re: Document type MK not allowed with doc. category F (Pl...
entry.content:
Go to OLME ‚Üí Define Document Types.  Select document type MK or the customized one. Ensure that:

  • Document Category = F (for contracts).
  • Release Order Indicator is set correctly.
  • Item Categories are appropriate for contract release.

If MK or the customized one is not properly configured for category F, you‚Äôll get the error you mentioned.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud RAP Custom entity unmanaged how to u...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question!

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

To update a custom entity in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition without updating the underlying table, you can use the concept of unmanaged scenarios in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP). In unmanaged scenarios, you have full control over the behavior of the entity, including how updates are handled.

Steps to Update an Unmanaged Entity

  1. Define the Custom Entity: Create a custom entity using the ABAP Development Tools (ADT). This entity will represent your business object.

  2. Implement the Behavior: In unmanaged scenarios, you need to implement the behavior of the entity manually. This includes defining how the update operation should be handled. You can use ABAP code to specify that the update should not affect the underlying table.

  3. Use EML (Entity Manipulation Language): Custom data as table, CDS, Domain, Business object‚Ä¶ - SAP Community EML allows you to perform operations on entities. You can use EML to update the entity without affecting the table. This involves writing ABAP code that specifies the update logic.

  4. Testing: Ensure that your implementation correctly updates the entity without modifying the table. You can test this using transaction codes or custom applications.

Example

Here is a simple example of how you might implement an update operation using EML:

DATA update_tab TYPE TABLE FOR UPDATE my_custom_entity.
update_tab = VALUE #( ( entityID = '001' fieldToUpdate = 'New Value' ) ).
MODIFY ENTITIES OF my_custom_entity
  ENTITY my_entity
  UPDATE FIELDS ( fieldToUpdate )
  WITH update_tab.
COMMIT ENTITIES.

This code updates the fieldToUpdate of my_custom_entity without directly modifying the underlying table.

For more detailed guidance, you may need to refer to specific documentation or tutorials related to the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model and unmanaged scenarios.

[1] Custom data as table, CDS, Domain, Business object... - SAP Community

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: Delta Sync Issue in SSAM 2505 with Basic Authentication
entry.content:
Assuming that users will be using different devices, you could try setting the runtime parameter 'USE_SMP_DEVICE_ID' to 'X'. Use program '/SYCLO/CORE_RUNTIME_PARAM_PROG' to set runtime parameter value. After the parameter is set, devices must be reset. Refer SAP note https://me.sap.com/notes/2713969/E for paramter details. Please note that cloud connector supports many types of authentication but for SAP Service and Asset Manager, it is recommended to setup with principal propagation (i.e., cloud connector SSO).

Best regards,
Sriram

entry.title: How to Implement Triangular Trade Intercompany Business in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I need to implement a specific Triangular Trade business model in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

The business scenario is as follows:

  • Company A (Customer) places an order with Company B (Ordering Company).

  • Company B receives the order and outsources the production to Company C (Manufacturing Company), which is in another country.

My main questions are:

  2. What are the key configurations and document types (e.g., Sales Order, Purchase Order, etc.) required for this process?

Any advice or guidance would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

 

Best regards,

Angie

entry.title: Draft Enabled RAP Object with association [0..*]
entry.content:
Hi,

we are seeing this strange behavior that seems to be a bug. We have developed a draft enabled managed BO.  This object has the following associations. Both of these associations are not part of object hierarchy.

association [0..1] to I_OfferType_VH as _Type on $projection.OfferType = _Type.OfferType
association [0..*] to C_OfferBUList as _BUList on $projection.OfferUUID = _BUList.OfferUUID

The first association is a simple case of type for a document. So when we modify the draft value, the association uses this draft value to determine new value of _Type. This works as expected. User changes the object property and the new values are immediately shown to the user. 

The problem is with the second association. Here we have an association to many ([0..*]). Based on the value of the root entity property, we determine a list of subsequent objects. The current value of draft is being ignored and the logic to resolve data of association is still using the value from the original object. Once the draft gets saved, it starts fetching the correct values. This is too late for us. In other words, the property value gets changed on draft but the corresponding association is still showing relevant entities resolved with the original value. 

Why does draft enablement work fine for association with [0..1] but does not work properly with [0..*]? Is this a limitation of Draft implementation or a bug? It seems like a bug to me.

The stack is ABAP Platform 2023.

entry.title: Re: Conversion Exits and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)
entry.content: @ThomasPostl yes exactly. To make the OData exposure work no such conversion exits may be in the list of relevant fields. These fields can be removed from the view building, casted a a different data element or removed from the exposure via annotation "@Consumption.hidden:true". As stated in many cases the converted value can just be joined via view building means. A solution that always works out is to hide the field from the consumption and add a new virtual element that gets the converted value.

entry.title: Migrating Integration Flows with JDBC on Cloud Foundry While Using SAP HANA on Neo
entry.content:
Migrating integration flows from SAP's Neo environment to Cloud Foundry (CF) can be a complex process, especially when dealing with extensive JDBC requirements. This blog post outlines a practical example of how to manage such a migration while keeping the backend database in Neo.

## Background

In scenarios where the backend database is hosted on Neo, organizations may prefer to migrate it at the very end of the transition process. This approach allows all migrated integration flows in CF and existing flows in Neo to continue interacting with the Neo database seamlessly.

  1.  Setting Up HANA Service in Neo

To begin, ensure your HANA service is properly set up in your Neo account. This setup is crucial for maintaining database connectivity during the migration process.

2. Exposing HANA Service via SCC
Utilize the Service Channel Concept (SCC) to expose your HANA service. This method ensures that both migrated and existing integration flows can access the Neo database without interruption. See  Configure a Service Channel for an SAP HANA Database.

3. Configuring JDBC Data Source in CPI

Next, configure the JDBC data source within the Cloud Integration capability environment. This step is essential for establishing a reliable connection to the Neo database. To add a JDBC data source, see Manage JDBC  Data Source

  • Sample Integration Flow

Here's a sample integration flow designed to read data from an employee table in the Neo database. This example demonstrates how integration flows can be executed successfully, ensuring data consistency and accessibility.

 

  • Execution Results

The execution results confirm that the integration flow can consume the HANA database on Neo via the SCC service channel concept.

In summary, this approach allows organizations to maintain database connectivity during the migration of integration flows from Neo to CF, ensuring a smooth transition without immediate database migration.

entry.title: Improvements on ADT method wizzard
entry.content:
Hello ABAPfreaks out there, 

I raised a ticket at SAP regarding creation of methods using the #ADT wizzard.
During the creation of methods using the Quick Assistant ( Strg + 1 ) parameter types are not correctly computed.




Example:

Data: t100 type t100.

"Success Case: 
t100-msgnr = any_class_instance->get_msgnr( ).     "Methode get_msgnr created using STRG+1 wizzard. Type detected correct

"Error cases - value Statement:
data: t100 type t100.

t100 = value #( msgnr = integra_file_dao->get_msgnr( ) ).         "type of returning is not determined -> ANY.  
t100 = value t100( msgnr = integra_file_dao->get_msgnr( ) ).  "type of returning is also not determined -> ANY. 


"Success Case 2

t100 = value t100( msgnr = conv msgnr( integra_file_dao->get_msgnr( ) ) ). " Typisierung wird auf msgnr erkannt.

 

 

3655122 - ADT improve type determination for quickfix to create method from call

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003655122

Note is available for:

Support Package

 Software Component VersionSupport Package 
 SAP_BASIS 754SAPK-75413INSAPBASIS 
 SAP_BASIS 755SAPK-75511INSAPBASIS 
 SAP_BASIS 756SAPK-75609INSAPBASIS 
 SAP_BASIS 757SAPK-75707INSAPBASIS 
 SAP_BASIS 758SAPK-75805INSAPBASIS 
 SAP_BASIS 816SAPK-81601INSAPBASIS

 

Enjoy better coding experience! 
Best Timo

entry.title: Re: Issue with setting up SF in Qualtrics
entry.content:
hi

Please follow the below

‚úÖ Steps to Resolve

  1. Check Your API Domain Configuration
    • Log into SuccessFactors Admin Center.
    • Go to API Center ‚Üí OAuth Configuration for OData.
    • Confirm that the domain you're using in Qualtrics is listed and approved.
  2. Register Your Domain
    • If your Qualtrics domain isn‚Äôt listed, you‚Äôll need to register it manually via the OAuth Client Application setup.
    • This involves uploading an X.509 certificate and specifying the correct domain during registration.
  3. Sovereign Cloud Considerations
    • If you're using a Sovereign cloud (e.g., for data residency or compliance), SAP may require additional approvals or configurations.
    • You might need to contact SAP Support to request that your Sovereign cloud domain be added to the API allowlist.
  4. Qualtrics Configuration
  • Ensure you‚Äôve followed all steps in Qualtrics for setting up the ETL task:
  • X.509 certificate creation
  • OAuth2 client registration
  • API key and domain setup in the Qualtrics task

 

Regards

Surjith

entry.title: SAC Advanced Formula Calculate with first of each month
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

For my planning scenario, I have two data models with different levels of date granularity.

1. Calculate product costs (date granularity: monthly).
2. Calculate profitability (date granularity: day).

When copying the calculated product costs from the first data model, I select the option to write the prices to the first element of each period. For example, the price from 25 September is copied to 1 September 2025.

However, I am now facing a problem when calculating the revenue. The quantities are planned at a daily level. Therefore, revenue is only calculated correctly on the first day of the month, as this is where the price was copied to.

I can think of two ways to solve this problem:

1. Copy the price from the 1^(st) of the month to each day in the current month.
2. Calculate the revenue by referencing the price on the 1st of each month.

I tried to create a data action for the second option using the FIRST() function. Unfortunately, this function returns the first day of the year, not of each month.

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Funktionsbereich] , [d/Sachkonto], [d/Kostenart], [d/Kunde],[d/CCW_Material], [d/Vertriebsweg], [d/Buchungskreis], [d/Profitcenter], [d/Sparte],[d/Verkaufsorganisation]

VARIABLEMEMBER #MENGE OF [d/Measures]

DATA([d/Measures] = #MENGE, [d/Funktionsbereich] = "#", [d/Sachkonto] = "#", [d/Profitcenter] = "#", [d/Sparte] = "#", [d/Kostenart] = "#") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Menge_ST")
// Herstellkosten = Menge * Materialkosten
IF [d/Funktionsbereich] = BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0100") 
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0120")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0110")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0300")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0301")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0140")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0130")
THEN
	FOREACH [d/Datum]
	DELETE([d/Measures] = "Umsatz")
	DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz", [d/Kostenart]= "#") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = #MENGE, [d/Funktionsbereich] = "#", [d/Sachkonto] = "#", [d/Kostenart] = "#")
	* RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Preis", [d/Kunde] = "#", [d/Datum] = FIRST([d/Datum].[p/CALMONTH]), [d/Profitcenter] = "#", [d/Sparte] = "#",[d/Sachkonto] = "#")*-1
	ENDFOR
ENDIF

Does anyone have a solution for this?
I am grateful for any assistance. Thank you in advance.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings
entry.content:
The new rules for automatic postings gradually replace existing functions such as net income calculations and reclassifications. These posting rules offer more capabilities, greater flexibility, and a modern user interface.

The following examples highlight the flexibility of the new rules:

  • Define source data flexibly, including field selections and period interval 
  • Assign multiple document types in one task
  • Include multiple posting lines
  • Define target data flexibly, including field assignment using attributes, and value calculation formula
  • Include results from previous rules
  • Use an enhanced partner filter for intra-unit eliminations.
  • Use the field assignment option 'Value Of ' to post on partner fields

-
Scenarios

With the rules for automatic postings, you can automate tasks such as:

  • Net income calculation for reported data while maintaining the same document type as the source data, and  also the original profit center or segment.
  • Reclassification of the inventory of finished goods to the inventory of semi-finished goods for manufacturing consolidation units.
  • Elimination of the inter-unit sales (reported by the selling consolidation unit) against the cost of sales in the partner unit (the buying consolidation unit).
  • Elimination of inter-unit receivables and payables against a balancing FS item to analyze the intercompany difference.
  • Elimination of intra-unit operations reported between different profit centers within one consolidation unit.

-
Components

Components

  1. When you run a task from the data or consolidation monitor, the system runs all the posting rules included in the rule group assigned to the task.
  2. Each rule selects source data and posts one or more posting lines. The rule automatically assigns the field values and calculates the amounts to post.
  3. The system creates a log that includes source lines, posting lines and any warning or error messages.

Use the following three new apps to manage the posting rules:

 

Rule Definition

Watch this video for guidance on defining a posting rule to calcule the net income:

 

Rule Type

You define a rule with one of the following rule types:

  • Net Income Calculation
  • Postings for Consolidation Units
  • Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs

The type determines which options are available or required. The rule type also determines the monitor (Data Monitor, Consolidation Monitor) where the rules can be carried out.

Examples: 

  • A posting rule that was defined with rule type Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs requires the Partner Units filter, and can be assigned to a task only in the Consolidation Monitor.
  • The option Post on Original Document Type is available only for the rule type Net Income Calculation.

Source Data

In this section, you define how the rule selects data. You can use:

  • A Selection defined in the Define Selections app.
  • A Period Selection, such as Year to Date, Prior Period, or Opening Balances.
  • Specific fields to include or exclude when reading data. Excluded fields are aggregated, improving the performance and the readibility of the log. 

Note: The values for Period, Year, Version, Consolidation Unit aren't aggregated.

Example: Only the fields Profit Center and Segment are read in the screenshot below. Details of other fields such as Cost Center aren't retained, and source values are aggregated.

  • You use the "Partner Units" option for elimination rules. In most scenarios you select the option "Partners in the Consolidation Group" . If the source data doesn't include a Partner Unit, you can select "All Partners (including empty)".

Example: Use this option to eliminate business operations between profit centers within a single Consolidation Unit, where there is no partner unit breakdown.

 

Target Data

In this section you define the measures (local currency, transaction currency, group currency, quantity) and document types for the postings. The available document types depend on the rule type. 

By selecting the document type in the rule you can group multiple automatic postings with different document types into a single task. This approach reduces the number of tasks you need to manage.

Example: You can define different rules for inter unit eliminations, such as sales and cost of sales, receivables and payables, or dividends. You can then group these rules into one single task and then post on different document types .

Posting Lines

Each rule must include at least one posting line, and can include multiple ones. To create a balanced posting, you need at least two posting lines. The number of posting lines doesn't determine the number of line items that will be posted. The number of line items depends on the granularity of the source data.

Example: If you define a rule with two posting lines to eliminate the internal sales FS item (posting line 1) against the cost of sales FS item (posting line 2), and your source data is broken down by segment and profit center, it include many lines. The rule will post for two posting lines for each source line.

Overview

In this overview you can create, display, delete, and sort posting lines.

Posting lines define how the source data is adjusted before posting. You can for instance assign a specific FS Item, clear the Material Number, or post to the Partner Unit.

Note: The posting line number is displayed in the log that is created when you run the task. This helps you to easily relate the posting line in the rule definition to the log entry.

Field Assignments

There are different ways to change the field values depending on the field. For FS items, you can assign values using attributes such as role and target attributes.  You can also select or clear a value, or post to the corresponding partner field. If you don't define a specific assignment for a field, the source value is kept.

In the example below the rule swaps the unit and partner fields for consolidation unit and profit center, assigns the functional area YB18 only when it is empty in the source data, and posts the FS item that is the target elimination of the source FS item.

Value Calculation

The value calculation determines the value to post on the measures selected for the target data.

You can use the following:

  • Mathematical operators: + - / * ( ) 
  • Constants: A number
  • Variables: Keyword SOURCE for the source amounts

Rule group

Watch this video to learn how to define a rule group:

 

In a rule group you select the rules to be carried out when you run the automatic postings task.

You can create nodes and subnodes to organize the rule group. For example:

  • Rules for net income calculation and reclassification of inventory of finished goods

 

  • Rules for inter-unit eliminations

 

 

In some scenarios you need to define that one rule "Depends on Previous Rules". This is necessary when the source data for the current rule includes data posted by the previous rule. When you select this option, the system updates the sequence column to show the order of processing.

Assign Rule Group

Once the rule group is defined with all the rules, assign it to the task using the app Assign Rule Groups for Automatic Postings.

You can define this assignment on several criteria:

  • Version: Depending on the configuration of the versions, the assignment can be valid for multiple versions. For example you can define an elimination task that carries out only the profit and loss eliminations for the planning versions, and all eliminations for actuals versions.
  • Time: Valid from Period / Year
  • Consolidation Units: For automatic postings tasks in the data monitor, you can restrict the assignment to selected consolidation units
  • Periods: you can restrict the assignment to certain periods. This allows one task to carry out different rule groups for a monthly (periods 1-11) or for a yearly consolidation (period 12).

Automatic Postings Run and Log

Watch this video to learn how to run a task for automatic postings and display the log:

 

You can change the log layout by selecting fields to display, and by defining grouping and sorting options.

The following fields help you analyze the log:

  • Item Type: Indicates whether the line is a source line or a posting line
  • Rule: The name of the rule that created the automatic posting
  • Posted Line: The number of the posting line defined in the rule
  • Source amounts and Posted amounts

-

entry.title: Do We Need a Separate Company Code for Hungarian Subsidiary?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I‚Äôm looking for some guidance on company code setup across countries and would love your expert input.

We have the following scenario:

  • A German company code exists and is fully operational.

  • The organization also has a subsidiary in Hungary.

  • We want to understand whether it‚Äôs mandatory to create a separate Hungarian company code in SAP, or whether we could run everything under the existing German company code.

Specifically, we‚Äôre considering two scenarios:

  1. Hungarian Legal Entity Exists

    • There is a registered Hungarian subsidiary (legal entity).

    • Can we still process sales and purchasing in Hungary under the German company code, or is it mandatory to create a separate Hungarian company code for local compliance, reporting, and taxes?

  2. No Hungarian Legal Entity Exists

    • The German company is doing business in Hungary directly (cross-border) without a registered Hungarian entity.

    • In this case, is it acceptable to use the German company code in SAP, provided we handle Hungarian VAT registration and tax obligations separately?

Our goal is to stay compliant while avoiding unnecessary complexity in SAP if it‚Äôs not required.

I‚Äôd really appreciate hearing from those who‚Äôve implemented similar cross-border setups:

  • How did you handle statutory reporting and tax compliance?

  • Any pitfalls or lessons learned?

  • Best practices you‚Äôd recommend?

Thank you in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Peppol Participant Registration for Belgian Companies
entry.content:
As of January 1, 2026, Belgian companies are required to exchange electronic invoices that are compliant with the European semantic and syntactic standard (EN 16931) with their business partners. The Peppol network is the secure network for this exchange, and companies need to register a participant for their company in this network. If you‚Äôre facing the task of registering your company in the Peppol network, this blog provides you with simple tips and guidance.

For more information about the Belgian legal change, see the Regulatory Change Manager or this blog Get Ready for the Mandatory Shift to E-invoicing in Belgium ‚Äì The Clock is Ticking.

 

How Belgian companies should register

The Belgian Peppol authority, BOSA (FOD Beleid en Ondersteuning - SPF Strat√©gie & Appui), has defined Peppol Authority Specific Requirements (PASR) for its area of application, according to which companies must first and at least register as a participant in the Peppol network using their company number provided by the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE). After this initial registration, companies can register more participants using the VAT number or other identifiers, such as a SWIFT code or a GLN.

The steps are as follows:

Step 1: Mandatory registration:

First, register your company as a participant in the Peppol network using your company number with party ID type "0208".

0208: This party ID type represents the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE), which assigns unique party IDs for companies operating in Belgium, for example: 0441797980.

Here are the detailed steps on how to create a participant in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: Creating a Participant for Your Company.

This creates a participant ID in the Peppol network consisting of the party ID type (it should be 0208 if it is your first participant) and the actual party ID for your company. As you can see, this participant ID is not given in advance by a government agency such as Peppol or a Peppol Access Point (AP) such as SAP.

Don‚Äôt forget to also register your company to receive electronic invoices: Registering Your Company to Receive Electronic Documents in the Peppol Network.

If your participant only exists in the Peppol network but is not yet registered to receive documents, you can send electronic documents through the Peppol network but can‚Äôt receive any.

Step 2: (Optional) additional registration:

In addition, you can register your company in the Peppol network using the company's VAT number, for example: BE0441797980, with the party ID type "9925". Other alternatives for the registration are the use of the generic ID ‚Äù0088‚Äù referring to the GLN or any other valid Peppol participant ID.

 

Migration from Hermes required

Hermes was an initiative by the Belgian government to advance electronic invoicing by enabling the receiving of electronic invoices in PDF format for receivers who are not (yet) able to process XML files.

All Belgian companies with a Belgian company number (party ID type: 0208) have been included by BOSA in the Hermes SMP (Service Metadata Publisher), which is part of the Peppol network.

If your company is ready to receive XML files, you must register your company using a Peppol Access Point like the cloud edition. However, if your company number is already used in Hermes SMP, your Peppol service provider needs to migrate it to the SMP of the Peppol Access Point. After this migration, you can then register your company number in the Peppol network as described in the previous section.

Support for SAP customers

If you are using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition as Peppol service provider, SAP migrates your company number for you from Hermes SMP to the SMP of SAP. To initiate the migration, create a customer case in SAP for Me with the title "MTCI migration required by Hermes SMP" under the component "LOD-LH-DRC-PAP". For other concerns regarding the electronic invoicing process, you can also submit a customer case under the component ‚ÄúCA-GTF-CSC-EDO-BE‚Äù.

 

 

I hope this blog was useful for you! You can leave a comment here or continue browsing our community for more blogs on SAP Document and Reporting Compliance topics.

entry.title: How SAP‚Äôs ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to open powerful opportunities for partners and developers who want to extend and integrate with  SAP Cloud ERP - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. To simplify this process, SAP provides an open-source reference: the ABAP Partner Reference Application.

The SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAP‚Äôs recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAP‚Äôs ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, it‚Äôs a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAP‚Äôs cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each step‚Äîfrom tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applications‚Äîis implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAP‚Äôs latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Clone the GIT repository, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration. Clone the main branch to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAP‚Äôs recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offerings‚Äîstreamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAP‚Äôs partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration‚Äîdirectly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensions‚Äîall with guided help from SAP‚Äôs own reference implementation.

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

It‚Äôs imperative that in today‚Äôs economy, data is more than just numbers‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

  1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 
  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

  1. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  
  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 

  1. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 
  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 

  1. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 
  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it‚Äôs not just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren‚Äôt just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap‚Äîit delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it. 

To read more about SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology check out SAP Discovery Center. 

‚ÄúOrganizations that adopt this framework position themselves to lead in the AI-driven economy‚Äù 

Previous blogs in the series:

  • SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions
  • SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
  • SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
  • Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4

Stay tuned for the next blog post in our ‚ÄòExploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework‚Äô series! 
SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Business Data Cloud RISE with SAP SAP Business Suite Data Management

entry.title: Re: In S/4HANA Public Cloud, what is the cds view that co...
entry.content:
Hello @Joey3 ,

1. There is released CDS view or API for cost element category within the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Therefore, it is not possible to rely on the existing CDS view to create custom logic. If the requirement is mandatory, please consider to use GL account type + GL Account or some other fields to create your custom logic.

2. The K_ACCOUNT_ASSIGNMENT_GET related to the SSCUI "Default account assignment", there is no existing CDS view for this customizing. The customizing data can be retrieved from the customizing directly.

It is recommended to check whether the requirement from business point of view can have some workaround with some other fields or use custom business object if required.

Kind Regards,
